Logic & Propositions.title: Logic & Propositions
Logic & Propositions.description: This chapter introduces Boolean logic, statements, logical operations, and truth tables used in reasoning and computing.

details: A proposition is a declarative sentence that is either true or false.
Propositions form the basis of mathematical logic.
Conjunction (P ∧ Q) is true when both are true.
Disjunction (P ∨ Q) is true when at least one is true.
Truth tables show outcomes of logical expressions.
Used to evaluate validity of statements.
Essential for circuit design and programming.
Two expressions are equivalent if they have identical truth tables.

sections.summary: Logic and propositions form the foundation of reasoning, algorithms, and digital circuit design.

Sets & Functions.title: Sets & Functions
Sets & Functions.description: This chapter covers fundamental set operations, functions, mappings, domains, and ranges used across computer science.

details: A set is a collection of distinct elements.
Cartesian product (A × B) forms ordered pairs.
A function maps each element of domain to one element in codomain.

sections.summary: Sets and functions build foundational structures for algorithms, probability, and relational models.

Relations.title: Relations
Relations.description: Relations describe connections between elements of sets and are used in databases, ordering systems, and logic.

details: A relation is a subset of a Cartesian product A × B.
Reflexive: every element relates to itself.
Transitive: if aRb and bRc, then aRc.

sections.summary: Relations define structured connections and support concepts like sorting, grouping, and database design.

Combinatorics.title: Combinatorics
Combinatorics.description: Combinatorics deals with counting, arrangements, and selections, essential for probability and algorithm design.

details: Rule of Sum and Rule of Product.
Used to calculate total outcomes in events.
Selections where order does not matter.

sections.summary: Combinatorics helps calculate arrangements and choices used in probability, cryptography, and complexity theory.

Probability.title: Probability
Probability.description: Probability analyzes uncertainty using random variables, likelihoods, distributions, and events.

details: Probability measures the chance of an event.
Sample space represents all possible outcomes.
Probability of event A given B has occurred.
Variables whose values depend on outcomes of random events.

sections.summary: Probability models uncertainty and supports analytics, ML algorithms, and decision-making.

Matrices.title: Matrices
Matrices.description: Matrices represent structured numerical data and support operations critical in graphics, ML, and linear algebra.

details: A matrix is a 2D array of numbers.
Used in transformations, equations, ML models.

sections.summary: Matrices form the backbone of scientific computing, ML modeling, and geometric processing.

Calculus Basics.title: Calculus Basics
Calculus Basics.description: This chapter introduces limits, derivatives, and integrals essential for understanding change and optimization.

details: Describe behavior of functions as variables approach a value.
Used in ML optimization and physics.
Used in probability, physics, and cumulative functions.

sections.summary: Calculus explains continuous change and is widely used in ML, physics, and engineering.

Linear Algebra.title: Linear Algebra
Linear Algebra.description: Linear algebra focuses on vectors, matrices, and transformations essential in ML, graphics, and engineering.

details: Used in physics, ML embeddings, geometry.
Used in PCA, ML dimensionality reduction.

sections.summary: Linear Algebra powers modern ML, physics simulations, and 3D graphics computations.

Graph Theory.title: Graph Theory
Graph Theory.description: Graph theory studies networks, connections, and traversal techniques used in social networks, routing, and algorithms.

details: A graph consists of vertices (nodes) and edges.

sections.summary: Graph theory enables understanding of networks, relationships, optimal paths, and tree structures.
